question.text: An angiosperm male plant having 24 chromosomes in its pollen mother cell is crossed with a female plant bearing 24 chromosomes in its root cells. The number of chromosomes in embryo and endosperm formed from this cross will most like be

solution.text: Pollen mother cell is diploid. Thus in the male plant <math><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi><mi> </mi><mo>=</mo><mi> </mi><mn>24</mn></math>. The male gamete will be haploid with <math><mi mathvariant="normal">n </mi><mo>= </mo><mn>12</mn></math>. The root cell is diploid. Thus in the female plant <math><mn>2</mn><mi>n </mi><mo>= </mo><mn>24</mn></math>. The egg will be haploid with <math><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mn>12</mn></math>. The endosperm is triploid <math><mn>3</mn><mi>n</mi><mi> </mi><mo>=</mo><mi> </mi><mn>36</mn></math> while the embryo will be <math><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi><mi> </mi><mo>=</mo><mi> </mi><mn>24.</mn></math>
